They added in a double-agent objective mechanic where you can choose what objectives to complete. Your decisions affect your trust with the Agency and the Terrorists. This is probably the most stealth-heavy title in the series so far, but it doesn't feel satisfying. Chaos Theory felt a lot better. 												I've had my fair share of bad ports on PC, however this one is... well, I can't even describe how bad it is. Let's start at the beginning. While the previous game of the franchise - Chaos Theory (yes, yes, one of the BEST stealth game of all time, however I won't go into further detail now) - got an update (1.05) to run in widescreen resolution (up to 1920*1200), this game did not, so you have to do some .ini tweaking to get the desired one. Since we're at tweaking, there are couple of options in the .ini which aren't even present in game (for tweaking and issue resolving I recommend this page: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Splinter_Cell:_Double_Agent ). Even after you've done everything in your power to make the game a bit better, the shadows frequently flicker or just outright don't appear.Then comes the sound: sometimes after loading the game, the game won't display a huge number of sounds (but you can still hear Sam's breathing, steps and muffled/glitched gun shots).Then comes the loading issue: the save system is abysmal, you have 3 spaces to choose which one you'd like to load from / save to, you can't rename your save files (maybe you can, but I got so frustrated with the menu that I'd rather used the quicksave/load option) and sometimes quicksaves just outright disappeared. This usually happened when the game crashed, I reloaded my game using the "Continue" option which did load the quicksave file, however after wanting the quickload said file, I couldn't. What?!I've written about the menu and how bad it is, but why you ask? Sometimes you can't navigate it with the keyboard (moreover it defaults to WASD rather then the arrow keys, but whatever), the mouse is janky and you can't use your mousewheel while browsing your save game files.The OPSAT (Sam's ~infobar on his wrist during the game) is also equally bad, has all the problems just mentioned."Okay okay, but how's the game play?" You might ask. Well I could have gotten over all of the above, if only it was good or at least not as bad as I've come to know it. One word: awful. The controls are sometimes unresponsive, Sam just doesn't want to grab that ledge or crawl into a ventilation system no matter hard you try (like he's also fed up with the whole game "Nope, not gonna do it"). More often than not you get stuck on some random object which can also lead you being discovered or just missing your chance.I might have missed some issues because there's plenty and I didn't write any of it down, all of this is just off the top of my head. A real shame though because it was a great idea executed so poorly...So the question is: would I *recommend* the game? NO. If you like Splinter Cell, just skip it, if you're a "hardcore" SC fan, then you might, only might, want to give it a shot.

												[4/10]    As much as I'd love to finish this game, I don't think it will even let me. The game crashes almost every mission for no reason, quick saves will randomly decide to not load, the entire game just freezes during certain loading screens. Also, the game looks awful compared to previous games in the Splinter Cell franchise, which is odd, considering Chaos Theory was absolutely gorgeous for its time, and still holds up to this day. Sometimes shadows won't even render when the level loads, making the whole stealth mechanic extremely awkward. Being a huge fan of Splinter Cell, it's really unfortunate that this game is unstable, to the point of freezing my computer. I could only recommend this game to hardcore fans of the Splinter Cell franchise. I will attempt to finish this game, and if it gets better, I will edit this review. Until then, this still stands.[EDIT]So I've finished the game. The bugs and glitches are still present, no suprise there, but there was one specific bug that stood out amongst others: a game breaking bug. After completing the final mission, a cutscene is supposed to play, the credits should roll, and you are rewarded with a bonus mission. For me, and many others, this didn't happen. The mission would end, and then cut immediately to an overhead scene of the level where you are unable to move and unable to quit properly. (you have to enter the Task Manager and end it manually.) Aside from the awful technical issues, the gameplay and story are some of the best in the Splinter Cell series so far. It takes place shortly after the events of Chaos Theory, in which Sam must pose as a criminal and join a terrorist force in order to destroy them from the inside. The game has a "trust meter," in which you have to complete objectives for the JBA: the terrorist force, and the NSA: the good guys. Due to trust being a factor, the game forces you to enter in these moral gray areas just to keep the trust of the enemy. While in the base, you have the option to research and spy on your allies/enemies to learn more info about them. This information will assist you in traversing the base as well as unlock special items for your missions. As with all previous games in the franchise, it is all based on stealth and using gadgets as well as the enviornment to your advantage to accomplish your objectives. If you've played a SC game in the past, you know what you're getting yourself into from a gameplay perspective. Summary: Splinter Cell: Double Agent is a fantastic game form a gameplay and story perspecrive, but it is hindered by so many techinical issues that it is not worth the purchase, at least not on the PC. I have heard that the concole version is much better, so if you would like to play this game, play it on the Xbox, PS2, or PS3.

For exemple if you put couch on ctrl, you will need to press ctrl to write a C, because the original key for crouch was C... The safe cracking game is horrible because it was obviously designed with a controller in mind. 												Summed Up: A really awful port to an otherwise pretty fun game. Buy this game on any other platform and you'll have a fun time, but avoid the PC version like the devil.In-Depth: I'll start with the game itself. It's not going to be anyones favourite Splinter Cell as, quite frankly, it's one of the more linear and demanding of the series. Gone is the option to play the game your way and still get the best score if you complete the objectives; now the game ranks you on stealth. It provides penalties to how many guards you knock out/kill, locks you break etc. Meaning you have to basically be a shadow to get the best score. This is a fair idea, but the problem is, the level often throws enemies at you you HAVE to move out the way, or you have to do something ridiculously convoluted to get them to move; which just takes up way too much time.Also introduced is the trust system; a fine line you have to take between both the terrorists and your employers. Alot of people were kind of iffy on this, but I honestly liked the idea. The main issue stems from the fact it's completely pointless. There are enough side objectives and such that you'll honestly always have full trusts 99.9% of the time; even on hard mode where you lose trust more and gain less. If they had made it much more imperitive to the game and maybe had it so you gained rewards from having certain levels, or even something as simple as dialogue change, it might have been  a worthy addition. As it stands, it's just kind of there; a nice idea that dosen't realise it's full potential. As for the core game, it's pretty much Chaos Theoy's mechanics again. This is fine as, in my opion, Chaos Theory really got it right when it came to the stealth aspect and design; n both games have a nice, easy to navigate ingame inventory, the layouts easy to see etc. One major gripe thought is that they changed the stealth meters; as in, they no longer exist. In Chaos Theory, they had two bars which showed your visibility and sound. This was useful as it indicated how alert enemies where sound wise and indicated clearly how sneaky you were being. In this game, you have a light, that's it. It's green when your safe, yellow when not, and red when spotted. The problem is, while it takes into account shadows and does change when enemies are more alert, it never shows how much noise your making; which can be a HUGE problem if your next to an alerted enemy and want to sneak past him QUIETLY. But, that aside, it is for all intents and purposes just more of Chaos Theory sanded down. Back handed as that is, I'm not complaining at  a few more levels.Now for the crux of the problem; the PC Port. The best summary would be 'A glitched up mess that everytime I play I find another'. The most common one is random crashes and lost autosaves, but there are weirder ones. Lost sound, not gaining your bonus equipment, a door not supposed to be there stuck in another door (Yes, that actually happened), do I need to go on? Not to mention graphically, the game just looks off. There is a guide to tweak this on steam, but the fact you HAVE to do this is pretty appaling; without the tweaks, the game looks... well, off, it's hard to explain, kinda like the world is slowly falling away pixel by pixel in the background. There are alot of things in this port that just make it dissapointing, and I really tried to look past them. But the bugs really were the final straw. Avoid the port like the devil, patches have been known to exist, but wether they work is apparently 50/50. Go buy another version of the game elsewhere; you'll be glad you did

												I've played through Double Agent on DVD shortly after it was released on PC. Somewhere near the end of the game (in one of the Kinsasha-missons), I got stuck. Everytime I tried to load a safe, I would spawn under the map, resulting in Game Over. When I recently discovered Double Agent on Steam, I picked it up. I was hoping that they fixed at least some of the bugs and I would finally be able to play through the story. Unfortunately, I was wrong.The engine is very buggy. Sometimes there's no sound, sometimes you get stuck. Many times, the game will crash when saving or loading. Saves are very unreliable: they either disappear or just don't work.The stealth isn't great. The levels are rarely dark. The sound- and lightmeter of the previous game(s) are replaced by a big light on Sam's back. That light indicates if you're hidden, not hidden, or spotted. It doesn't always work: often you're supposedly hidden, but a guy at the other side of the map can still spot you. Sometimes you're not hidden, but there's a huge snowstorm going on and a guy on the other side of the level still raises the alarm. Especially on "Hard"-difficulty, not getting spotted is VERY strict.The interface is ported almost straight from the console-version. The inventory and interactions are kinda slow to use, as you have to cycle through them. There is no way to bind different weapons or gadgets to keys on your keyboard. You can't just plug in a controller to play this game. One positive note: you can use the Steam Controller set to KB/M-bindings. That works pretty well. The options in the menu are very limited. You can select "Normal" or "Next-Gen" graphics, and resolutions up to 1600x1200 pixels. Not all keybindings can be changed. The list of saves is very short, so you have to scroll a lot (and as mentioned before, the saves often don't work).There are some good things about this game, too. The story is arguably the best part of this game. The undercover-aspect is a fresh approach which works well enough. There are some very interesting locations, and they often look well (for their age). And finally, it is more Splinter Cell.If you are a die-hard Splinter Cell-fan, you might be interested to pick this up. But be warned that the experience might be troubled by technical difficulties or can be plain frustrating. If you're new to series or only a casual fan, check out the other games like Chaos Theory of Blacklist.=====TL;DR=====+ Story+ Locations+ Undercover+ Splinter Cell- Interface for controllers- No support for controllers- Unreliable saving / loading- Very limited menus- Many crashes- Many bugs- Average stealth:* It's barely dark* Enemies are super sensitiveConclusion: Double Agent is a very bad port which suffers from many bugs and is often frustrating. Only get if you're a very big Splinter Cell-fan.

(Online Servers are Shutdown)You choose the Pro's and Con's here becuase some people may argue about which is a pro and con and which is'nt.Summery Review: Splinter Cell Double Agent is a Third Person Action Stealth Shooter Released in 2006 as part of the Splinter Cell Series by Ubisoft and Tom Clancy. Splinter Cell Double Agent has alot of improvements from the previous title Splinter Cell Chaos Theory. The first really big Noticable Change from the previous title Chaos Theory is the graphic's. Splinter Cell Double Agents Graphics when it first released were updated from Chaos Theory but games grow old and with age comes with updates. Several of said updates added significant improvements to graphic's and added more options than before. Some other changes include new animations being added, more stability for modern system as well as compability for out-of-date systems (If your computer really is that old). Next thing players are gonna notice right off the bat when first playing Double agent is the length and difficulty of the missions. Double Agent Contains many things that no other splinter cell has one of them being the extreme length of the mission. These missions can be very comparable to the missions we seen in the original splinter cell and may take 40+ minutes to finish. The AI has gotten Tougher in this title and I found it hard to complete missions and playing on the hardest difficulty seemed nearly impossilbe due to the AI's ability to seemlessly shoot you through the wall but that is made but for by it's "Call of duty Style" 1-3 Shots results in the player dying. The game will get you through about 11 hours of total gameplay before beating the story I have owned this game for years and always find myself going back and restarting the game just to find that one area I never discovered or could never get into because it always seemed near impossible to get into without getting killed or detected. Replayability is also fun to find those computers that you may have missed or forgotten about with some splinter cell lore contained. One thing Splinter Cell Double Agent Introduced to the splinter cell Series in Unlockables. Unlockables in splinter cell double agent is obtained by completing "Star Objectives" which are usually optional objective but completeing them unlocks equipment that give the player an advantage in there undercover black operations within john brown's Army" Splinter Cell double Agent did include a CO-OP Mode with a Seperate story portrayed by the two characters from the previous splinter cell co-op Story mode but the servers were shutdown and the mode is no longer available. There is a feature in this game exclusive to double agent allowing the player to make story effecting decision's. Such Decisions will effect the Trust Meter between the NSA and the JBA. If the player allows one of these meters to expire the mission fails immediately until the player increases the expired meter. During the Beginning of the Story another Double Agent Exclusive Feature is found in the game which is Snowy enviroments. During the Beginning of the game Sam is given his "First Real Test" mission by the JBA and is taked with hijacking a supertanker Somewhere within Northern Russia and the Entire Mission is a Snow Enviroment where the player has to navigate through a blizzard and a white out which can be very difficult even when using the Goggles. Continuing on with the double agent exclusive feature, Underwater enviroments and combat. In Splinter Cell Double Agent we find a feature that is not in any other splinter cell that allows the player to swim around in water and submerge under. During the Mission to Hijack the Supertanker and the Very First mission in Island the player has the ability to surface but will be blocked by frozen water and has to cut through it to reach the surface. If there is an enemy on the ice above the player, the player has the ability to grab through the ice and pull there victim under and stab them to death. If the Victim is on an ajacent Shore by the frozen water or unfrozen even, the player also has the ability to take care of them this by pulling them off the shore and under the water.Conclusion: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell is a pretty dated game from the Early 2000's but The game introduced alot of feature we see in Splinter Cell Conviction and Blacklist. Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Contains many things only seen in Double Agent that I would like to see in future splinter cell titles. The Game has excellent graphics for its age. The difficulty for this game is a bit much when going into the hardest difficulty settings due to the AI being able to shoot through the walls at the player. I recommend this game I think its an excellent title and I think it brought us some great features that we see in modern titles and future titles. Some Exclusive Features such as the ability to use water as cover and a means of killing your enemy id like to see in future titles. I had alot of fun beating it years ago and still do today.

For instance killing innocents will couse the Echelon to be displeased with you, therefore players ability to stay hidden and avoid contact with the enemy is rewarded. My favourite part of the game ere the semi-sandbox levels which take place in terrorist hideout. In these the player is given a main and sideobjectives from both terrorists and echelon and has around 30 minutes to complete as many of them as possible. 												Some games do not age well. And Splinter Cell: Double agent is a great example of that. There is a lot of things wrong with the game and not many that were done right. I finished the game but there were times I thought about not trying to.Lets start with bad then shall we.The game crashes. And it crashes a lot. And there is no pattern just when will it crash. Sometimes in the middle of the mission, sometimes on mission load, sometimes on intro or outro of the mission. And sometimes it works just fine for an hour or longer. But on other times crashes after ten or fifteen minutes. Quite annoying. And once you decide to exit game, it can freeze itself forcing you to restart the windows in order to regain control.The graphics are aged and it shows. Fact that highest resolution is 1600x900 does not help either. To top that the first mission is really ugly which makes matters even worse at first. You get used to it later on and it's not that bad as the first impression.Audio seems fine most of times. Though lack of subtitles is extremely annoying. This was almost a reason not to play the game. The game does not introduce itself very well. It lacks that modern tutorial/guide style so present everywhere. This is somewhat refreshing but leaves a lot for player to figure out. Some things I've learned on almost ending missions. But the lack of waypoints saying exactly where to go was a bit of back to the roots trip. When you actually had to figure stuff out instead of going after the flashing blip. The story is rather bland. The start of it a disaster I would say. It gets a bit better later on but it is not to original or interesting at that. Mechanically it's not too good as well. The three vision mode, night, head and electronics are pretty much useless. I don't think I used them even once in a meaningful way. Shooting and combat are bad. Most annoying thing being - why the hell is a pistol more accurate than a rifle? I mean really. Grenades are useless as well.As a stealth game it fares much better. Sneaking is satisfying as much as stabbing the guys in the back. Most of the missions can be completed by remaining stealthy which is nice. Safe cracking is a nightmare though. The controls for it are terrible.That should be about time to tell something good about the game. So what it does going for it are pretty well designed levels and missions. They're interesting and challenging. Some of them are approachable by different ways I guess though it's not the same amount of freedom as Hitman games for example. Also the JMB headquarter levels are very nice - especially with the trust mechanic. This is the only part that makes the game worth playing. Time you are given to complete some additional objectives really adds to the double agent atmosphere.Overall I'd say 6/10 if you disregard the crashes. Not really something I can wholeheartedly recommend though I've played worse games.

												6 out of 10This is the 4th episode in the Splinter Cell series.  You play as Sam Fisher, an operative in 3rd Echelon a top secret NSA black-op outfit.  Its all about stealth, not so much on killing. If you haven't played any Splinter Cell game yet, what?  Where have you been.  These are great games.  However, you should not start with SC Double Agent. This game is for SC veterans who want to do it all.  I started on this game three times.  Only the last time did I bite the bullet and stuck through.  Unfortunately compared to the previous SC games this one is slightly disappointing.  The good: 1. Decent stealth based action.  Shooting is not what its about and the shooting system has never been a strong point in any SC game - it is very static. The bad: 2. Where is the luminosity meter?  Knowing when shadows are enough to cover you is a guessing game. 3. The choices you make have no discernable impact on the game.  Only the cut-scenes. 4. What is the story all about?  Some people want to blow up the USA, but why? 5. The characters are as thin as wet paper.  Sam's daughter is killed off at the start, why? 6. You unlock lots of equipment.  When do you actually get to use it? The ugly: 7. Horrible stability issues.  My game crashed about five times per mission. 8. Character model getting stuck in the scenery. Dam, in retrospect there where not many good points.  Thank goodness the game is relatively short.
